item.title: Middle East Crisis: Gaza Cease-Fire Negotiators Meet Amid Threat of Wider Conflict
item.description: Hamas said it wouldn’t participate in the meeting, dimming hopes for a breakthrough to end Israel’s war against the armed group.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Five Possible Candidates to Lead Japan
item.description: Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party is searching for a successor to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. But is it willing to change to appease a dissatisfied public?
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan announced on Wednesday that he would not run for office again when the Liberal Democratic Party chooses a premier next month.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Reopens Border Crossing for Aid to Famine Zone
item.description: Accused of blocking food aid for its starving people, Sudan’s military announced it would reopen the main border crossing with Chad, which it had closed for six months to U.N. relief trucks.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recently arrived refugees from Sudan at a refugee camp in Adré, Chad, last month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Kursk Region of Russia Flips the Script on Putin
item.description: The reality of 130,000 displaced Russians and a chaotic official response may begin to puncture the official line that Russia is steadily heading toward victory.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Alina Lobzina
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians displaced from the border regions waited for aid on Tuesday in Kursk.

item.title: A Mob Attack on a Toppled Party Shows Bangladesh’s Dangerous Vacuum
item.description: A cycle of vengeance is playing out even as the interim government is trying to establish reforms and keep order.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mob attacked a man in Dhaka on Thursday whom they suspected of having ties to the party of the ousted prime minister.

item.title: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 12 Years in Prison on Treason Charges
item.description: Ksenia Karelina is accused of donating $52 to a New York-based nonprofit that sends assistance to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ksenia Karelina in court in Yekaterinburg, Russia, in June. She was tried on treason charges related to money she gave to a New York-based nonprofit group that aids Ukraine.

item.title: Brazil’s Maid Rooms Reveal Country’s Racist Past And Are Disappearing
item.description: In Brazil, rooms for maids, a vestige of the country’s history of slavery, are disappearing or being transformed as the country confronts deeply ingrained inequities.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and María Magdalena Arréllaga
item.media:description: Older apartment buildings along one of Copacabana’s main avenues in Rio de Janeiro. Many still have small rooms once reserved for maids.

item.title: Why Protesters Are Calling for Safer Hospitals for India’s Doctors
item.description: The death and apparent rape of a physician trainee reignited rage over violence against women and prompted nationwide protests by colleagues.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Medical students and doctors protesting in Kolkata, India, on Wednesday, after a junior doctor was found killed.

item.title: Yulia Navalnaya Disputes Russian Report on Cause of Husband’s Death
item.description: The Russian authorities said Aleksei A. Navalny had died of a grab bag of diseases, including heart arrhythmia triggered by hypertension.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning Aleksei A. Navalny in Moscow in March.

item.title: Argentina’s Former President Fernández Beat First Lady, Prosecutors Say
item.description: A domestic violence scandal has rocked Argentina since Alberto Fernández, the country’s former president, was accused of abusing his partner, Fabiola Yáñez. He has denied the allegations.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Daniel Politi
item.media:description: Former President Alberto Fernández of Argentina was accused by prosecutors of hitting Fabiola Yáñez, his partner during his presidency.

item.title: Macron Honors African Soldiers Who Helped Liberate France in World War II
item.description: Two months after D-Day, an Allied force dominated by soldiers conscripted from French colonies swept into southern France. It’s a chapter of its history that France has long obscured.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, rear center right, with World War II veterans of the Allied landings in Provence at a ceremony in Boulouris-sur-Mer on Thursday.

item.title: On Anniversary of Taliban Takeover, Glee, Mourning and an Embrace of Jihad
item.description: Celebrations marking the third year since the U.S. withdrawal are amplifying a divide in Afghanistan over what principles it should be governed by.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:description: Celebrating the third anniversary of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan in Herat on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Claims to Capture Sudzha, Zelensky Says
item.description: The fall of Sudzha, about six miles from the border, would be Ukraine’s first capture of a Russian town since its troops crossed into Russian territory 10 days ago.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite photograph showing a damaged hangar at the Borisoglebsk air base in Russia after an attack by Ukrainian drones on Wednesday.

item.title: Portraits of Survival: The Israeli Hostages Who Made It Home
item.description: They are now trying to rebuild their lives, campaign for the return of the hostages still in Gaza and mourn for those who were killed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Is Chosen as Thailand’s New Prime Minister
item.description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, a 37-year-old daughter of the political power broker Thaksin Shinawatra, is becoming prime minister at a chaotic time.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was chosen on Friday to be Thailand’s next prime minister, has a thin résumé, having played only advisory roles in government.

item.title: Typhoon Ampil Lashes Eastern Japan, Forcing Evacuations
item.description: The authorities have warned that the storm, which has already flooded some streets in the Tokyo area, could bring violent winds and cause landslides.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Typhoon Ampil neared eastern Japan on Friday, felling trees, forcing evacuations and causing widespread travel disruptions.

item.title: Ski Passes and Weber Grills? Obscure Perks of a U.S. Alliance
item.description: The military alliance between Australia and the United States is growing ever close�r. But how does the superpower value its smaller ally? Here are some clues.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:description: A 2021 satellite image of the Joint Defense Facility Pine Gap, Australia.

item.title: Giant Panda in Hong Kong Gives Birth to Twins
item.description: Ying Ying is the oldest panda on record to give birth for the first time. Also unusual: her cubs were naturally conceived, a rarity for the vulnerable species.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Ocean Park Hong Kong, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In this photo released by Ocean Park, a Hong Kong theme park, twin panda babies, female at left and male at right, are seen. They were born on Thursday, in a first for Hong Kong.

item.title: An English Shepherd Dog Went Blind. Now She’s Helping Other Pups Avoid Her Fate.
item.description: Shola, who assisted with search-and-rescue operations in the U.K., has moved to her second act: saving other English Shepherds from blindness.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: As Shola’s eyesight dimmed, scientists at the Canine Genetics Center at the University of Cambridge studied her DNA. She was diagnosed with progressive retinal atrophy.

item.title: Israeli Settlers Storm West Bank Village, Drawing Rare Rebukes From Israeli Officials
item.description: The Palestinian Authority said one person was shot dead; the Israeli military said it was investigating and condemned the attack, as did the Israeli prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A column of Israeli armored vehicles leave following a military operation in the West Bank town of Tubas.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Resume, but Hopes Are Muted Amid Fears of Wider War
item.description: Negotiators met in Qatar for the latest round of negotiations on a deal that would end the fighting and perhaps reduce escalating regional tensions, but Hamas did not send representatives.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Doha earlier this year. The Qatari capital is the scene of talks aimed at stopping the fighting in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Ukraine Takes a Russian Town
item.description: Plus, with one room, Brazil confronts its racist past.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the destroyed Russian border post at Sudzha on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia Reveals a Dramatic Shift
item.description: The offensive was developed in secret, devised to divert Russian troops away from the front lines in Ukraine and seize territory to use as a bargaining chip.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The incursion is one example of how Ukraine is taking the initiative, exposing Russian weakness and embarrassing President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: New Israeli Settlement in West Bank Would Encroach on Protected Land, Peace Now Says
item.description: An advocacy group, Peace Now, said that Israel was accelerating new claims over West Bank land in a bid to prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Battir, a Palestinian village in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, is a UNESCO World Heritage site.

item.title: America Can’t Produce the Weapons It Needs for the Future. This Could Help.
item.description: The United States, Australia and Britain are making it easier to share defense technology, hoping to spur the innovations needed to keep up with China.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The leaders of Australia, the United States and Britain gathered in San Diego last year to discuss a submarine alliance.

item.title: 5.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Taiwan
item.description: There were no immediate reports of major damage, but the island’s fire department warned of the risk of landslides in mountainous areas.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: Typhoon Ampil Approaches Japan, Disrupting Flights and Trains
item.description: The powerful storm is expected to bring heavy rain, strong winds and the threat of floods and landslides to eastern Japan, including Tokyo, on Friday.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Some of Japan’s Shinkansen bullet trains will be suspended on Friday because of Typhoon Ampil.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s goals in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: American officials say Israel’s continued bombings in Gaza are only increasing risks to civilians.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks: What Has Happened and Where Things Stand
item.description: As tensions in the Middle East escalate, negotiators are set to meet in Qatar to try to reach an agreement to end the war in Gaza. President Biden said he was “not giving up” but that it was “getting harder” to remain optimistic.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Rabbi Shmuel Butman, 81, a Brooklyn Voice of Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Is Dead
item.description: He was the public face of the Chabad-Lubavitch sect during the Crown Heights riots in 1991 and for decades lit its giant menorah in Manhattan every Hanukkah.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Rabbi Shmuel Butman speaking before the New York General Assembly in 2017. He regularly engaged with elected city and state officials as a leader of the Brooklyn-based Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic sect.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Assesses Israel’s War in Gaza
item.description: Plus, a fake Elon Musk scam.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: The war in Gaza has gone on for more than 10 months with only a one-week pause in November.

item.title: In Gaza, Israel’s Military Has Reached the End of the Line, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Israel has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: American officials say Israel’s continued bombings in Gaza are only increasing risks to civilians.

item.title: Mpox Outbreak: What to Know About Symptoms and Risks
item.description: The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency over an outbreak that has spread to more than a dozen African countries.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: A Congolese health worker speaking with relatives and discharged patients about hygienic measures to follow after recovering from mpox last month near Goma, North Kivu Province.

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Mpox Outbreak in African Countries a Global Emergency
item.description: The epidemic is concentrated in the Democratic Republic of Congo, but the virus has now appeared in a dozen other African countries.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A laboratory nurse, with samples taken from a patient with a suspected case of mpox near Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: 2 Bases in Germany Placed on Heightened Alert Over Suspicious Episodes
item.description: The discovery led to the temporary lockdown of the base while the water supply was tested. NATO officials also reported that an intruder tried to forcibly enter one of the alliance’s bases in the country.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: The German military base in Cologne-Wahn was sealed off on Wednesday.

item.title: Whimsical Parade of Banksy Animals Sends Fans on a Giddy Hunt
item.description: Each day for nine straight days, a new Banksy artwork appeared somewhere in London. For some, it became a citywide treasure hunt.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: People view a new artwork by the British artist Banksy above the Bonners Fish Bar takeaway restaurant in Walthamstow, in London, Britain, August 9, 2024.

item.title: Germany Issues Arrest Warrant for Ukrainian Over Nord Stream Explosion
item.description: The sabotage of the pipelines that carried Russian gas to Europe has become one of the central mysteries of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Danish Defence, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Danish Defense Ministry of a vast swirl of bubbles on the surface of the Baltic Sea in international waters between Denmark and Sweden in September 2022.

item.title: Russia Begins Moving Some Troops From Ukraine to Repel Kyiv’s Offensive
item.description: Russia has begun moving some troops from Ukraine to deal with a Ukrainian incursion, the U.S. and Ukraine say. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw units from hot spots in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing a roadside crater minutes after a Russian strike near the border in Ukraine’s Sumy region on Tuesday.

item.title: Thai Premier Srettha Removed From Office on Ethics Charges
item.description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was considered a figurehead leader in a behind-the-scenes power struggle. He was ousted on ethics charges.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin of Thailand at a news conference in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: How Extreme Heat Is Threatening Education Progress Worldwide
item.description: Children today face many more extreme weather hazards that can undermine global gains in education.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Extreme heat in May closed some schools in the Philippines. Students did schoolwork near a Manila storefront.

item.title: Ceasefire Talks on Sudan’s Civil War Open in Switzerland
item.description: The American-backed talks in Switzerland, which started on Wednesday, aim to halt a catastrophic civil war. But only one side has turned up.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recently arrived Sudanese refugees from the Darfur region wait in line to receive food on the outskirts of the Adré refugee camp, in Chad, last month.

item.title: New Zealand Charity Accidentally Gives Away Meth Disguised as Candy
item.description: Police were racing to recover the fake sweets, each of which contained up to 300 doses of methamphetamine. Three people sought medical attention.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: China’s Extreme Fan Culture Makes Olympic Gold a Mixed Blessing
item.description: Fans have mobbed athletes in public and staked out their homes. State media outlets denounced their “visibly aggressive” behavior.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Ma Long, the captain of the Chinese men’s table tennis team, being greeted by fans at an airport after returning to Beijing on Monday. His team won gold at the Paris Olympics.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The details of Ukraine’s military offensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing a destroyed Russian border post.

item.title: UK Asylum Seekers Are Still on Edge After the Far-Right Riots
item.description: Abdulmoiz, an asylum seeker from Sudan, feared for his life when far-right rioters tried to set fire to the hotel where he was housed. The violence has eased, but he is still afraid.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police faced off with crowds during an anti-immigration riot this month at a Holiday Inn Express near the town of Rotherham, England.

item.title: To Save the Panama Canal From Drought, a Disruptive Fix
item.description: In the wake of a drought that hampered shipping, the Panama Canal’s overseers are eager to expand water storage. Climate change leaves them no choice.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman and Federico Rios
item.media:description: Visitors at the Panama Canal, the economic heart of Panama.

item.title: Fumio Kishida, Japan’s Prime Minister, Will Step Down in September
item.description: The unpopular prime minister is bowing to pressure within his party. But it is unclear whether the party is truly ready to choose a candidate who will meet the public’s concerns.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan after a news conference in Tokyo on Wednesday. Mr. Kishida has been Japan’s prime minister since 2021.

item.title: Deadly Landslides in India Made Worse by Climate Change, Study Finds
item.description: Extreme rainfall made 10 percent heavier by human-caused climate change triggered landslides that killed hundreds, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Rescuers searching through mud and debris after landslides in Wayanad district in Kerala, India, on Aug. 1.

item.title: Hunter Biden Sought State Department Help for Burisma
item.description: After President Biden dropped his re-election bid, his administration released records showing that while he was vice president, his son solicited U.S. government assistance.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The release of records came as Hunter Biden prepares to stand trial next month on charges of evading taxes on income from Burisma and other businesses.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Hamas Will Skip Upcoming Talks
item.description: Plus, in Russian territory captured by Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Protesters marched on Saturday for a cease-fire deal and to return Israeli hostages in Gaza.

item.title: Hamas Will Not Attend Gaza Cease-Fire Talks as Mediators Try to Secure Deal
item.description: Hopes for a breakthrough were damped after Hamas said it would not attend the peace talks set for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians watching the aftermath of an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Tanzania Arrests 520 People in Mass Opposition Crackdown
item.description: The clampdown came after the police banned a youth rally and pointed to the anti-government protests that have swept neighboring Kenya in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Freeman Mbowe, the chairman of the Tanzanian opposition party Chadema, was among those arrested before a planned rally.

item.title: How Ukrainian Troops Invaded Russia
item.description: Planned in secrecy, the incursion was a bold move to upend the war’s dynamics and put Moscow on the defensive — a gambit that could also leave Ukraine exposed.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut, Alina Lobzina, Eric Schmitt and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing through a destroyed Russian border post this month.

item.title: Seven Pro-Palestinian Activists Charged Over Break-In at Israeli Arms Company’s U.K. Site
item.description: Prosecutors argued in court that pro-Palestinian activists had vandalized a site belonging to Elbit, an arms manufacturer, and had committed offenses with a “terrorist connection.”
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The entrance to the Elbit site near Bristol, in March. Last week, a protest group called Palestine Action broke into the building and smashed items inside. Police said its members also attacked officers and a security guard.

item.title: Head of Panel That Ruled Against Jordan Chiles Represents Romania in Other Cases
item.description: The decision outraged U.S. Olympic and gymnastics officials, and led to a torrent of online abuse against both Chiles and Ana Barbosu, the Romanian athlete who ended up with the bronze.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jordan Chiles, right, with Simone Biles, left, and Rebeca Andrade after the floor exercise final last week in Paris.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut, Kim Barker, Anton Troianovski and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian men carrying a dead Russian soldier in a body bag after finding him in the rubble of a destroyed Russian border post on Monday.

item.title: Fires Near Athens Leave a Path of Destruction
item.description: The Greek authorities said the threat posed by the blazes had lessened as of Tuesday, thanks in part to an overnight lull in the strong winds. But the risk remained.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Walking through charred farmland in the area of Chalandri, northeast of Athens, on Tuesday.

item.title: On the 75th anniversary of the Geneva Conventions, the war in Gaza resonates.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A hospital staff member on Monday looking at the bodies of Palestinians inside the morgue at Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.

item.title: Israel Was Less Flexible in Recent Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Documents Show
item.description: The country made five new demands, according to documents detailing its newest negotiating positions.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel denied that he had added new conditions and said that he had instead sought to clarify ambiguities in an earlier proposal.

item.title: Why China’s and Russia’s Militaries Are Training Together
item.description: The two countries have held joint exercises near Alaska, Taiwan and Japan in defiance of the United States and its alliances.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian military in July purporting to show U.S. and Canadian jet fighters near a Russian bomber during a joint patrol exercise with Chinese military planes near Alaska.
